column4: ok, so uh that wiki didnt help me for starting SSH at all, just for creating a key ...
and only the DSA key, not the RSA
if you install openssh-server, it is set up and started automatically
openssh-server is already the newest version.
You lost me now.  You were asking about creating the keys and starting the server, and I said that doing apt-get install openssh-server creates the keys and starts the server automatically.
so where are we now?

sorry for the confusion really, but apparently i was trying to setup SSH for a friend to access my box, foo actually, well then apparently i got some weird errors, then  i came to you, did apt-get install and it said i have the latest versoin, but when i attempt to start the service i get an error with DSA and RSA keys not found
ah, ok.  we can try a dpkg-reconfigure.  if that fails try to uninstall the package and then install it again.
thanks
try uninstall, then install.

fool told me to pastebin my error, its quite weird, i unsintalled, reinstalled, it created keys during installation fine and all, but refuses to start, take a look please, it would be ever so appreciated =)
looking
thanks !
do ls -l /etc/ssh       make sure all the files are owned by root, group root, and permissions -rw-r--r--  (for ssh_host_dsa_key and ssh_host_rsa_key  -rw-------)
if that looks normal, I would erase all the files in that directory and do the uninstall and then install again (Or reconfigure, if that worked)
erase all the files in /etc/ssh.   back them up first, though, to be safe.
-rw------- is correct for ssh_host_dsa_key and ssh_host_rsa_key
I'm thinking that /etc/ssh/ssh_host_dsa_key is corrupted or damaged.  I would erase the files in /etc/ssh and then uninstall and install.  (or dpkg-reconfigure, if that worked)
alright thanks ill do that, however im pretty sure dpkg worked, there were no errors, should i try that again first ?
yes, I would.  delete the files in /etc/ssh, do the reconfigure, then do an ls -l of /etc/ssh
if reconfigure creates the files, then you should be ok.  by the way, do    ps aux | grep sshd    to make sure ssh isn't already running
I don't think it is, with a corrupted file, but check it anyway, since it only takes a second.
thanks a lot, ill try to let you know what happpens
